title: Lavender Tallow Balm: What Actually Happened to My Winter Skin
body:
My face was basically a science experiment gone wrong last December. It was like, 10 degrees outside, and the air in my apartment was so dry from the heater. My skin just gave up. It wasn't just dry. It was tight. It was flaky in weird patches near my eyebrows. It felt like I was wearing a mask made of sandpaper. I tried everything. I mean, I spent so much money. That fancy La Mer cream my friend swore by? Felt like water. The CeraVe in the tub everyone on Reddit loves? Just sat on top of my skin, a weird filmy layer. The Kiehl's Ultra Facial Cream? Nada. My skin was still thirsty. And angry. I was about to just smear Vaseline all over my face and call it a life.

Then I saw someone talking about beef tallow balm. For your face. I was scrolling on my phone, one leg tucked under me, and I just stopped. Beef fat. On your skin. My first thought was, obviously, "That sounds kind of gross." And also, "Will I smell like a steak?" But I was desperate. My knuckles were starting to crack. So I looked it up. Found this little shop on Etsy selling a whipped tallow balm, specifically a lavender one. The pictures looked nice. Simple jar. They said it was made in France from grass-fed cows, whipped up so it wasn't just a block of grease. I was skeptical. So skeptical. But my credit card was out, and I clicked buy. It was a Tuesday night, I think. Maybe Wednesday. The heater was clicking on and off.

## How I Started Putting Beef Tallow on My Face

It showed up a week later. Small jar. Kind of heavy for its size. I opened it in my kitchen, under the weird fluorescent light. The texture was... unexpected. Thick. Like really thick. But also soft? You could scoop it, and it held its shape for a second before melting. I put a tiny bit on my finger. It was cool. Then it just kind of vanished into my skin. No greasy residue. Just... gone. And the smell. Okay, this is where I have to be careful with words because I hate those perfume descriptions. It didn't "smell faintly of" anything. It smelled like lavender. But not like a cheap candle or air freshener. It was a deeper, herby smell. Calming. Like the plant itself, crushed. I stood there sniffing it for a minute. My cat looked at me like I was insane.

I was still nervous. Beef fat. On my face. I washed my face, patted it dry, and took the tiniest amount. Rubbed it between my palms to warm it up. It turned almost clear. I patted it all over my face. It absorbed. Like, really fast. My skin felt... quiet. Not instantly moisturized, but not tight anymore. It just felt neutral. I went to bed thinking, "Well, at least I'll smell nice." I woke up the next morning and my face wasn't a desert. That was new. The flaky patches were smoother. Not gone, but less... crusty. I kept using it. Morning and night. Just that. I stopped using my twelve-step routine. Just cleanser and this tallow balm.

Here's a random thing. I told my sister about it. She called me while I was making coffee, and I was just like, "So I'm putting cow fat on my face now." Dead silence. Then she laughed for a solid minute. But then I told her my skin wasn't cracking anymore, and she got quiet. She has eczema. She ordered some the next week.

## Why This Tallow Stuff Actually Makes Sense

I did some reading after it started working. Because I was confused. Why would this work when a $300 cream didn't? Turns out it's kind of simple. Our skin produces sebum, right? That's our natural oil. Beef tallow, especially from grass-fed cows, is apparently really similar to human sebum. Like, structurally. So your skin recognizes it. It doesn't just sit on top as a barrier—it gets absorbed deep down because it's familiar. It mimics what our skin already makes. That's the whole thing with natural skincare, I guess. Using stuff that our biology already understands. This particular balm is whipped, which just means it's got air whipped into it, so it's lighter and easier to spread than just a chunk of fat. It's not a fancy chemical. It's just... fat. But the right kind of fat.

My winter damage was no joke. Chapped lips? Gone. I'd use a little on my lips before bed. The fine lines around my eyes, the ones that looked worse when I was dehydrated, seemed less... dramatic. Not erased. I'm not saying it's magic. But they looked softer. Like my skin was actually hydrated from the inside, not just coated on the outside. It made sense in a way that all the hyaluronic acid and peptides never did. My skin just needed its own kind of oil back.

## What My Skin Looks Like After a Few Weeks of This

So it's been a couple months now. I'm on my second jar. I keep it on my nightstand. The lavender scent is legitimately relaxing. It's become part of my bedtime thing. Wash face, slather on this balm, the smell fills the room for a second, and I just pass out. It's like a signal to my brain that work is over. Anxiety relief? Maybe. Or maybe it's just a nice smell that I associate with sleep now. Either way.

The results are the thing, though. My skin isn't "perfect." I still get a spot sometimes. But it's balanced. It doesn't feel like a brittle leaf about to crumble. It feels resilient. When I wake up, my face is soft. Not oily. Just soft. My elbows, which were always rough, are smooth for the first time ever. I use the leftovers on my hands after I do my face. My cuticles aren't a mess. I was so skeptical about this tallow balm for dry skin, and now I'm the person telling people about it. My mom asked what I was using because my "skin looked glowy” over Christmas. I had to explain it to her twice.

I got mine from this Etsy shop, The French Tallow Co. or something like that. The jar is simple, no crazy packaging. It feels honest. I like that.

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Yeah, weirdly. From what I understand, because it's so close to our skin's own oils, it absorbs deep and really nourishes it. It's not just a surface-level fix. It helped my winter skin more than anything else.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
I was worried about this. My skin can get congested. But this stuff absorbs so completely. It doesn't feel like it's sitting there blocking anything. It's non-comedogenic, which means it shouldn't clog pores. It hasn't for me.

**What does lavender tallow balm smell like?**
It smells like real lavender. Herbal, a little earthy, not sweet or fake. It's strong when you open the jar but fades to a soft scent pretty quickly. It's genuinely calming. Perfect for a night cream.

Anyway. If your skin is being difficult, especially in the winter, and the usual stuff isn't cutting it, this might be worth a shot. I didn't expect much. But honestly? It just works. I don't know what else to say. I'm probably gonna order another one soon.
